Rationale  Agriculture accounts for 39% of the national gross domestic product 
(GDP), and employs about 70% of the total workforce. Rural income 
is primarily generated from agriculture, which is dominated by rice 
production. Despite the importance and potential of agriculture, its 
growth during the 1990s has been sluggish and has widely fluctuated 
due  to  its  heavy  dependence  on  rain-fed  rice  cultivation.  The 
country’s average rice yield was estimated at 2.1 tons per hectare 
(ha)  in  2001,  the  lowest  in  Southeast  Asia.  During  the  First 
Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDPI, 1996–2000), the average 
growth of agriculture was less than 3.0% per annum (with high 
variability), which was far below the plan target of 5.2% per annum, 
and had no substantial impact on poverty reduction in rural areas. 
 
With  assistance  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the 
Government implemented the first Agriculture Sector Program (ASP, 
1996–2000),  including  reforms  to  address  land  legislation, 
agricultural  inputs,  rural  infrastructure,  rural  finance,  public 
enterprises,  and  decentralization.  Although  ASP  was  generally 
successful, the Government recognizes that the reform measures 
introduced under ASP needed deepening to accelerate agricultural 
growth. Regulations for the Land Law, enacted in August 2001, need 
to  be  prepared  and  implemented.  In  keeping  with  the  goals  of 
reorienting  public  agencies  and  promoting  private  sector's  role, 
further progress in divestment of state-owned public enterprises is 
warranted.  New  regulations  and  regulatory  capacity  must  be 
developed to maintain the quality and safety of agricultural inputs 
traded in the market. Further efforts are also required to improve the 
policy  and  institutional  environment,  and  the  Government's 
administrative capacities that will promote private sector participation 
in  the  agriculture  sector,  particularly  in  marketing  and  financial 
services, and training and education. To remove knowledge and 
technology constraints on agricultural productivity, the Government 
must continue to improve the skills and resources of the national 
system for agricultural research and extension.  
 
Under  the  Second  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPII, 
2001–2005), the Government aims to transform agriculture into a 
driving force to improve economic growth and reduce poverty within 
a  market-oriented  policy  framework  by  promoting  agricultural 
commercialization  and  diversification.  In  line  with  SEDPII,  the 
Government wishes to continue, with ADB's assistance, its policy

facilitating  agricultural  commercialization  and  diversification.  The

Risks are mainly related to difficulties anticipated in (i) approval and

monitoring of ASDP implementation and conduct effective dialogue 
with the Government. ADB will closely coordinate with the World 
Bank, which will initiate the social land concession program on a 
small-scale pilot basis.

early divestment of agricultural public enterprises. ADB was informed

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Agriculture Sector Development Program (ASDP). The 
report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Supporting Policy and Institutional 
Reforms in the Agriculture Sector, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under 
the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
2.  Cambodia's gross domestic product (GDP) per capita was estimated at $282 in 2001, 
making it one of the least developed countries in South and Southeast Asia. On account of its 
social capacity for human development, Cambodia is in the lowest tier of the medium human 
development category and ranked 130th, with its human development index in 2001 estimated 
at 0.556, and its gender development index at 0.551 (105th), one of the lowest in Asia.1 
 
3.  About 36% of the country's population is estimated to live below the poverty line,2 with 
about 90% of the poor living in rural areas, where the incidence of poverty is about 40% or four 
times that for Phnom Penh. Poverty in rural Cambodia is pervasive with a large proportion of 
rural population also living near the poverty line, presenting both an opportunity for a substantial 
reduction of poverty with the right policies and a danger of a rapid increase with inaction. The 
characteristics of poverty differ across the country: (i) limited access to productive resources 
and low productivity in the south and southeast, (ii) displacement and resettlement in the 
northwest, and (iii) poor human development indicators in the mountains of the northeast. 
Poverty is particularly prevalent among vulnerable groups affected by the long civil conflict: 
internally displaced people, returned refugees, and war widows. 
 
4.  Reducing poverty by emphasizing rural development was the primary development goal 
of the First Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDPI, 1996–2000), which highlighted food 
security and transition to market-based agriculture. Key components of SEDPI included (i) 
provision of better access to improved agricultural inputs; (ii) improvement in rice yields and 
reduction in production loss due to irregular weather conditions; (iii) promotion of livestock 
production,  particularly  by  improving  animal  health;  and  (iv)  promotion  of  commercialized 
agriculture. Central to this were institutional, regulatory, and policy reforms to introduce a 
framework conducive to market-based agricultural growth. 
 
5.  Cambodia is predominantly agrarian, with agriculture representing 39% of GDP, and at 
least 70% of rural population directly dependent on agriculture for their livelihood. Of the total 
cropped area of about 2.6 million hectares (ha), 90% is planted with rice (2.3 million ha in 2000), 
which is the primary staple, providing about 70% of nutritional intake on average, with per capita 
consumption needs estimated at 151 kilograms (kg) of white rice.3 Agriculture is important to 
reduce rural poverty and improve the capacity for human development. Within the agriculture 
sector, crops and fisheries are the most important sub-sectors with 46% and 32% of agricultural

6.  Under SEDPI, national GDP was targeted to grow on average at 7.5% per annum, with 
agriculture expected to achieve 5.2%. Domestic political conflicts in 1997 and the regional 
financial crises of 1997 and 1998, combined with the severe floods of 2000, reduced overall 
GDP growth rate during the period to 6.7% per annum and agricultural growth to less than 3.0% 
per annum on average (with high variability), well below the SEDPI targets. Overall poverty in 
Cambodia is estimated to have declined during the SEDPI period but this was largely due to 
significant reduction in urban poverty led by the growth of the garment sector. Slow agricultural 
growth means that the sector provided no major impetus to reduce rural poverty, and the 
linkage between agriculture and the rest of the rural economy was thought to have weakened. 
Many of the new entrants to the labor force have thus had to be absorbed into relatively 
unproductive employment in agriculture. 
 
7.  However, the Government introduced important institutional and policy reforms during 
the SEDPI period with assistance of external funding agencies, including ADB’s first Agriculture 
Sector  Program  (ASP).4  ASP  initiated  several  reform  measures  to  establish  a  policy  and 
institutional framework for market-based agricultural growth, and resulted in (i) enactment of the 
2001 Land Law to improve security in land tenure and ownership; (ii) introduction of mass media 
programs  to  provide  better  access  to  agricultural  technology  and market information; (iii) 
reorganization of state-owned public enterprises and establishment of a regulatory framework 
for agricultural inputs in the market; (iv) launching of a divestment process for state-owned 
rubber estates (SOREs); (v) introduction of a rural road maintenance plan and budget; (vi) 
establishment of a legal and regulatory framework for rural finance development; and (vii) 
decentralization  of  development  activities.  ASP  was  generally  successful.  However,  the 
Government  recognizes  that  reforms  needed  deepening  to  fully  capture  the  benefits  of 
agricultural growth and poverty reduction. 
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Government Objectives and Strategy 
8.  The  Second  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPII,  2001–2005) was officially 
launched  in  July  2002.5  Its  main  development  objectives  are  to  (i)  promote  broad-based 
economic  growth  to  improve  the  livelihood  of  the  poor,  (ii)  facilitate  social  and  cultural 
development, and (iii) ensure the sustainable use of natural resources and sound environmental 
management. To achieve these objectives, the Government aims to improve the country's 
governance environment and attain higher economic growth. GDP is projected to grow at an 
average rate of 6.1% per annum during the plan period.

9.  Under SEDPII, the Government has shifted its focus from food security, which was the 
core strategy of SEDPI, to agricultural commercialization and diversification. The Government 
now aims to transform agriculture into a driving force to achieve higher economic growth and 
reduce rural poverty. The Government's public investment program for 2001–2003 is expected 
to allocate $210.2 million to the agriculture sector or about 12% of the total program amount. 
However, at present, the allocable budget ceiling for  the agriculture sector is limited. The 
strategy of SEDPII for the agriculture sector is to (i) promote a consistent macroeconomic and 
agricultural  policy  framework  for  a  liberal  and  market-oriented  trade  environment  by 
deregulating agricultural input and output markets; (ii) establish policy and legal frameworks for 
effective  land  management  and  administration;  (iii)  accelerate  sustainable  irrigation 
development; (iv) strengthen essential agricultural support services; and (v) develop quality 
standards for  agricultural inputs. To promote agricultural growth, the Government wishes to 
continue and enhance, with ADB's assistance, the policy and institutional reform measures 
introduced under the first ASP (para. 7), and resolve critical issues restricting the sector's 
performance through focused investment. 
 
10.  In  line  with  SEDPII,  the  rolling  medium-term  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy 
(NPRS)6 for 2003–2005 has been prepared by the Government with active participation of civil 
society organizations and assistance of external funding agencies. NPRS builds on SEDPII but 
seeks to clearly define and implement the Government’s approach to poverty reduction. NPRS's 
central objective is to mainstream efforts to reduce poverty, shifting from a series of projects to 
integrated budgetary support. NPRS aims to reduce rural poverty by addressing (i) inadequate 
access to land; (ii) weak management of water resources; and (iii) lack of rural infrastructure. 
Access to land and water is highlighted as the fundamental natural resources forming the basis 
for economic growth and poverty reduction, especially in rural areas where people rely on them 
for agriculture. Besides land and water, key elements of the agricultural strategy also include 
improved access to effective research and extension services, quality inputs, and markets. 
 
11.  SEDPII and NPRS stress the need to improve productivity and value added of rural land 
and labor. While food security is being addressed, the dominance of subsistence or near-
subsistence production of low-value rice undermines efforts to raise incomes and generate 
employment in rural communities. The lack of linkages with agro-industries is also seen as 
limiting the value-added potential of agriculture and its multiplier effects through industry and 
services. Emphasis is, therefore, put on commercializing agriculture, and creating links with 
processing and support services. However, a number of impediments still hinder this approach. 
ASDP is designed to help overcome such impediments  or reduce their significance through 
support for market-oriented initiatives in policy and institutional reforms and through direct 
investment to improve public sector services. 
 
2.  Access to Resources and Inputs 
12.  The revised Land Law was enacted in August 2001 to ensure consistency with the 
Constitution,  and  clear  legal  definitions  and  terminology  about  land  ownership.  However, 
establishment and granting of agricultural land titles remain problematic, and many disputes are 
still being reported. Land concessions are also the subject of much debate because of their 
relevance to strategies for rural development and poverty reduction, and the issue is highly 
political. By November 2002 the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries (MAFF) had 
granted 25 land concessions for agricultural production, covering about 724,000 ha under

contracts with concessionaires (mainly from 1998 to 2001). MAFF further reported that only 10 
concessions initiated planting, involving about 14,000 ha or less than 2% of the total concession 
areas. The remaining concession areas are unused due to absence of infrastructure for access 
and land disputes. 
 
13.  Under the 2001 Land Law, land concessions should not exceed 10,000 ha unless 
justified by evidence of actual investment and needs. This limit is to be applied to existing and 
new  concessions,  necessitating  renegotiation  of  concession  contracts  and  revocation  of 
concessions over this limit. Strict application of the limit is expected to release at least 412,000 
ha  of  land  designated  for  agriculture,  which  would  provide  ample  resources  to  promote 
productive economic concessions and to allocate land to the landless. There will be a potential 
for increasing various income-generating activities for the poor, and examples of the integration 
of smallholder and estate agriculture can be found across Southeast Asia. The Government 
thus  recognizes  the  need  to  (i)  reduce  unused  economic  land  concessions,  (ii)  further 
accelerate the securing of land titles for farmers, and (iii) implement the 2001 Land Law through 
the issuance of necessary subdecrees and guidelines. 
 
14.  Most crop production in Cambodia is rain-fed. Irrigation is often supplementary and 
season-specific rather than year-round. Even this supplementary irrigation is limited, covering 
only 16% of the total rice growing area. In addition, a flood recession system of production is 
used on 7% of the area. As a result, almost all rice is single-cropped and highly dependent on 
rainfall. Under the first ASP, new approaches to irrigation management and maintenance were 
tested based on the formation of farmers' water user communities (FWUCs). Eleven pilot 
schemes are being pursued under the MAFF's medium-term work program for 2001–2005. A 
water law is being reviewed at the National Assembly, and a new statement on water policy 
drafted, incorporating the commitment and mechanisms for sustainable small- and medium-
scale irrigation schemes. In parallel, the Government is increasing investment in irrigation 
projects with assistance from bilateral and multilateral funding agencies, including ADB. 
 
15.  Farmers' access to improved seeds and other inputs is still limited due to their lack of 
awareness  of  the  benefits  of  using  improved  seeds  and  other  required  inputs.  Important 
contributions are being made to the production and dissemination of improved rice seeds by the 
Cambodian Agricultural Research and Development Institute (CARDI) with support from the 
Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  and  by  the  World  Bank’s  Agricultural 
Productivity Improvement Project. However, total production of improved rice seeds is still small 
(about 400 tons), barely enough to cover the needs of most farmers. To improve the legal and 
institutional framework for seed production and distribution, the Government is drafting a seed 
law,  which  aims  to  promote  the  private  sector's  role  in  improving  seed  production  and 
distribution. This is an important step to initiate the promotion of the seed and planting materials 
industry  in  Cambodia.  Other  important  areas  also  need  to  be  addressed:  quality  control 
measures, regulatory enforcement mechanisms and capacity building. The projects financed by 
other funding agencies are involved in these areas. The Government also issued a subdecree 
and established the Bureau of Agricultural Materials Standards within MAFF in October 1998 to 
provide a regulatory framework to protect farmers and other users of agricultural inputs (seeds, 
fertilizers,  pesticides,  veterinary  medicines,  feeds  and  feed  additives)  from  adulteration, 
commercial  exploitation  and  dangers  to  health  as  a  result  of  low-quality  products  and 
inappropriate packaging. Much remains to be done, particularly to address issues such as the 
presence  of  unmarked  and  concentrated  chemicals,  and  over-adulteration  of  products,  by 
strengthening the bureau's capacity and raising awareness of these issues among farmers.

5 
16.  Farmers often report that limited access to finance is a major impediment to adopting 
improved technology to raise productivity, diversify into higher-value commodities, and establish 
processing and service enterprises. Rural outreach by formal financial institutions is extremely 
limited and there appears to be a serious level of mistrust in formal financial institutions among 
rural population. Numerous non-government programs provide small-scale credit although their 
overall impact is small. Licensed microfinance institutions also have sizeable loan portfolios and 
broad area coverage.7 Still, deficiencies of rural finance, involving savings mobilization and 
credit  provision,  are  major  impediments  to  developing  commercialized  agriculture.  In 
collaboration with other multilateral financial institutions, ADB is addressing the issue of the rural 
financial system under the financial sector program.8 
 
3.  Market Environment for Private Agro-Based Enterprises 
17.  During the first ASP period, the Government initiated steps for withdrawing its direct 
intervention  in  production  and  marketing  of  agricultural  and  agro-based  products.  In the 
agriculture sector, the Government owns seven rubber estates, Agricultural Inputs Company 
(AIC), and Kampuchea Fish Import and Export Company (KAMFIMEX). While SOREs remain 
active producers constituting about 80% of the total rubber exploited area of the country, the 
other two enterprises' activities have been significantly curtailed as private companies have 
increased their market shares. SOREs have been posting losses for a number of years and 
appear to drain resources from the rubber sector. Continued state ownership impedes the 
growth of the whole rubber sector by restricting development of smallholder or family rubber 
producers and by constraining smallholder processing and marketing of rubber. The impaired 
quality of estate rubber also constrains the promotion of Cambodian rubber in the international 
market. It is reported that this results in the lower price of Cambodian rubber by 15–20% as 
compared to that of other countries' rubber, which is certified for international standards, and 
seriously  affects  smallholders'  income.  Thus,  SOREs'  operationally  and  financially  poor 
performance hinders efficient use of resources and points to a lost opportunity for development. 
 
18.  State ownership of AIC and KAMFIMEX also uses scarce public resources for redundant 
operations, and provides uncertainty in the agricultural input and output markets about possible 
state interventions in future. Bureaucratic procedures and informal government pressures for 
social and political imperatives restrict the day-to-day management of public enterprises. AIC, 
which is supposed to distribute agricultural inputs, has not had any business recently and has 
been paying administrative expenses, including salaries of its 55 staff, from the receipt of 
interest on cash assets. Given that the private sector sufficiently meets input supply, there is no 
clear justification for the state ownership of AIC, and the Government recognizes the need to 
facilitate AIC's divestment. KAMFIMEX had a monopoly of fish exports until 2000, when export 
of live fish and fish products was liberalized. KAMFIMEX still acts as an agent for small fish 
traders, allowing export under its license, with a fee to cover customs duties and other charges. 
KAMFIMEX currently has 103 full-time staff and 40 fishermen associated with its fishing lot. 
Though it became an autonomous public enterprise in September 2002, KAMFIMEX's financial 
performance has not been made public yet.

4.  Institutional Framework 
19.  MAFF was the lead executing agency for the first ASP and implemented it satisfactorily. 
MAFF operates a standardized planning process using procedures that are reasonably well 
established. MAFF's current organizational structure was adopted in April 2000 through a 
subdecree establishing 12 line departments.9 Planning capacities are variable among MAFF 
departments partly because of variable training and capacity-building programs in the past. 
Core functions among the departments are unclear, particularly in the role of policy planning 
and management, and due to the mixture and overlapping of service delivery functions. The 
Government  recognizes  a  strong  need  to  review  the  structure  to  clarify  the  roles  and 
responsibilities of these departments within MAFF in a market-oriented agriculture sector. The 
reorganization of MAFF needs to be carried out based on such a review and the renewed 
strategy for human resource development in line with the Government's decentralization policy. 
 
20.  The Government has been pursuing accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO). 
The action plan to comply with membership conditions in various areas has been implemented 
satisfactorily.  In  July  2003,  WTO  completed  its  work  for  Cambodia's  membership  and 
recommended it in September 2003. The Government has established a task force to address 
WTO issues in the agriculture sector. Several important aspects regarding harmonization of 
regulations and procedures relate to plant protection and animal health. The Government has 
also established a WTO unit in MAFF to implement regulations and prepare new regulatory 
systems to ensure the quality and safety of agricultural and agro-based products in accordance 
with WTO provisions. 
 
5.  Gender in the Agriculture Sector 
21.  Women constitute more than half the farming population, and are engaged in various 
agricultural activities, including seed selection, transplanting and harvesting in rice farming, and 
caring for household members. Women also do milling and pounding of paddy for household 
consumption. The gender division of labor is not entirely rigid but men expect to be paid more 
for remunerative activities. Women farmers are also active in homestead vegetable production 
and small livestock for subsistence and cash income. However, their access to improved 
knowledge  and  technology,  and  productive  resources,  including  financial  services,  is 
substantially limited due to their unrecognized social role, inadequate literacy and socio-cultural 
inhibition in the villages. Women are under-represented  in  agricultural  institutions.  Female 
extension workers are less than one third of the total extension staff at the local level. The 
situation is even worse at MAFF's central offices. Female students are under-represented in 
agricultural  universities  and  colleges.  To  increase  the  effectiveness  of  agricultural  support 
services, women farmers' access to such services must be increased through sector-wide 
improvement in mainstreaming of gender issues. The Government has long recognized this 
need  in  the  agriculture  sector  but  progress  has  been  rather  slow.  During  SEDPII,  the 
Government  aims  at  establishing  a  sector-wide  institutional  framework  for  gender 
mainstreaming. 
 
6.  Agricultural Support Services 
22.  Following liberalization of markets from 1989 to 1996, the Government clearly lacked 
information  about  market  conditions  and  opportunities  at  home  and  abroad.  Agricultural 
activities and development strategies of the Government continued to be production rather than

market oriented. Small markets, however, exhibited strong competitive characteristics with a 
large number of small retailers, middlemen and wholesalers. Product prices were largely set by 
traders on the basis of privileged information about domestic and regional markets. Under the 
first ASP, the Agricultural Marketing Office was established, and staff trained. A survey to 
assess the impact of the market information services (MIS) was undertaken in 1998. The 
assessment indicated that it benefited about 80% of farmers and traders, and strengthened

and market analysis, survey methodologies and data management systems.  
 
23.  Under  SEDPII,  the  Government  intends  to  raise  value  added  in  agriculture  by 
diversifying into higher-value products, and increasing downstream processing and related 
services. Undermining this approach are low yields and uncertain quality of products. With the 
country's scarce resources to improve access to agricultural technology, research efforts must 
be client oriented and highly focused on resolving issues that have the most immediate impact 
on the users of research. A national policy for agricultural research and extension was approved 
by the Government in October 1998 to improve the delivery and use of research and extension 
services, dwelling extensively on institutional issues to make them more effective at addressing 
the  critical  issues.  Crucially,  research  institutions  were  to  be  divorced  from  direct  MAFF 
management  to  support  intellectual  independence  and  budgetary  autonomy  to  allow  for 
commitment to medium- and long-term research programs. The national policy also emphasizes 
the  need  to  strengthen  coordination  among  research  institutes,  universities,  government 
agencies and the private sector. 
 
24.  The agricultural extension services receive only about 2% of MAFF's total recurrent 
budget despite their importance in improving farm productivity. Inadequate allocation of budget 
for district and provincial extension services hampers delivery of support services for farmers 
and  affects  service  quality.  MAFF's  extension  services  have  been  long  supported  by  the 
Government of Australia since 1995. Technology extension has also been supported through 
various area development projects financed by other external funding agencies. However, as 
the Australian support will be gradually reduced, MAFF urgently requires an increased budget to 
maintain even the current level of support services. Additional resources are also needed at the 
district and provincial levels to complement efforts of area development projects and expand the 
coverage  of  extension  services  to  areas  with  greater  potential  for  commercialized  and 
diversified agriculture. The Government is also trying to raise motivation of extension staff and 
make them more accountable by removing the system of patronage that normally determines 
career development and undermines incentives. 
 
7.  Current Policy Environment 
25.  A major thrust of government policy has been towards the decentralization of decision-
making  and  the  deconcentration  of  public  service  delivery,  and  these  have  become  key 
elements in the drive to strengthen governance, promote administrative reforms and reduce 
poverty. Before the commune council elections in February 2002, the average Cambodian had 
little  contact  or  knowledge  of  commune-level  administration.  The  election  introduced  a 
representative level of local government; 11,261 councilors were elected to 1,621 commune 
councils, with 5- 11 members in each council. Commune councils are still in their infancy and

8 
generally have only one clerk.10 Efforts for deconcentration of service delivery have been 
directed at strengthening capacity of line ministries at the provincial level, including for service 
delivery through district offices. A number of ministries have begun to assess the potential 
service delivery role for commune councils. Accordingly, the current policy of the Government is 
to  fully take into account the deconcentration of public service delivery in implementation 
arrangements proposed for new public sector projects in the agriculture sector. 
 
26.  In 2000 the Government announced its decision to introduce a medium-term expenditure 
framework (MTEF) to budget planning in priority sectors, including the agriculture sector.11 
MTEF aims to provide a medium-term rolling process and mechanism for continuity to link 
development  plans,  multi-year  programs,  and  annual  recurrent  budgets.  This  approach  is 
expected  to  increase  the  effectiveness  of  public  expenditures  in  pursuit  of  development 
objectives. The MTEF approach will be introduced into the agriculture sector for the 2004- 2006 
framework during ASDP. To make the approach effective, MAFF's central role in policy and 
planning needs to be strengthened in parallel by rationalizing MAFF departments (para. 19). 
 
8.  External Assistance 
27.  Total external assistance to the agriculture sector in Cambodia amounted to about $35.4 
million in 2001 on an annual disbursement basis, including multilateral (54%) and bilateral 
(43%) agencies, and international nongovernment organizations (NGOs) (3%). Since 1992 ADB 
has provided 24 loans, amounting to a cumulative total of about $620 million on a commitment 
basis, and 101 TAs totaling about $68 million. Eight loans, including portions of emergency 
assistance loans,12 for a total of $158.7 million or about 26% of the ADB's total committed loan 
proceeds, are for agriculture and rural development. In the agriculture sector, the largest bilateral 
funding source is Japan, followed by France, Australia, and Denmark. Other major external 
funding  agencies  in  the  agriculture  sector  in  Cambodia  include,  among  others,  European 
Community, Food and Agriculture  Organization of the United Nations, International Fund for 
Agricultural  Development,  and  World  Bank.  ADB  has  been  active  in  ensuring  adequate 
coordination  with  other  external  funding  agencies  through  working  group  meetings  of  the 
consultative group of external funding agencies in agriculture and natural resources. External 
funding agencies involved in agriculture and rural development will be regularly briefed on the 
progress  of  ASDP  implementation  at  these  working  group  meetings.  The  development 
coordination matrix is in Appendix 2.

10.  ADB's Operational Strategy for the Agriculture Sector 
30.  ADB's current operational strategy in Cambodia focuses on the three priority areas: (i) 
rural economic development, (ii) human resource and social development, and (iii) private 
sector development.14 A new country strategy and program is expected in early 2004. It can be 
strengthened by sharpening its focus on implications of the state reform program and by 
enhancing the impact of sector interventions on poverty reduction. The stable macroeconomic 
environment  will  continue  to  make  ADB  operations  more  effective.  ADB  agrees  with  the 
Government  that  critical  constraints  on  agricultural  growth  and  productivity  need  to  be 
addressed under ASDP in line with SEDPII and NPRS of the Government. Farmers' better 
access to productive resources, a favorable market environment, and improved inputs are 
critical to increased productivity, production and farm income. ASDP has been formulated in this 
conceptual framework. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Objective and Scope 
1.  Objective 
31.  ASDP aims to promote sustainable growth of the market-based agriculture sector in 
Cambodia, and thereby contributing to overall economic growth and poverty reduction. ASDP 
will facilitate agricultural commercialization and diversification in line with SEDPII and  also 
ensure that the poor and women increasingly participate in agricultural production, marketing, 
and post-production system. The program framework is in Appendix 3. 
 
2.  Scope 
32.  ASDP's  overall  scope  will  include  support  to  (i)  improve  farmers'  ability  to  raise 
productivity and diversify into higher-value products, (ii) improve the market environment for 
private agro-based enterprise growth, and (iii) strengthen institutional capacity for competitive 
agricultural commercialization. A development policy letter, describing the Government's reform 
measures under ASDP, with a policy matrix, summarizing the sequence and specific actions, is 
in Appendix 4.

B.  Important Features 
33.  The need to integrate farmers into rapidly growing urban markets and international trade 
is at the core of ASDP's approach to sustainable agricultural growth and poverty reduction. 
ASDP includes a range of measures to provide support for this broad framework. The general 
principles  adopted  in  formulating  ASDP  were  (i)  consistency  with  SEDPII  and  NPRS,  (ii)

efforts, and (iii) close linkage between the program component and the project component. The

C.  The Program Loan 
1.  Objectives 
34.  Within the overall framework of ASDP, the program loan aims to facilitate policy and 
institutional reform measures to ensure a favorable environment for market-based agricultural 
growth. The loan will (i) provide better access to productive land, water, improved seeds, and 
other agricultural inputs of good quality; (ii) improve efficiency of rubber production, and ensure 
no direct state interventions in the agricultural input and output markets; and (iii) facilitate 
agricultural commercialization by strengthening and rationalizing agricultural institutions, and 
providing access to improved support services. 
 
2.  Components and Outputs 
a.  Access to Productive Resources and Inputs 
35.  The 2001 Land Law gives the poor and the landless improved access to unused state 
land. For this purpose, a subdecree for social land concessions15 was approved by the Council 
of Ministers on 19 March 2003. This also fulfilled the Government's commitment made to the 
consultative group of external funding agencies. Adequate consultations with key stakeholders 
have been conducted for the finalization of the draft subdecree with assistance from ADB's 
ongoing TA.16 Under the subdecree, the Government will distribute unused land to eligible 
households  for  productive  purposes.  Initially,  a  small-scale  pilot  project  for  social  land 
concessions will be implemented under the World Bank's Land Management and Administration 
Project. Within a year the Government is expected to complete the implementation guidelines 
for  the  subdecree  to  establish  screening  procedures  for  potential  social  land  concession 
programs and provide adequate control over competitions for state land. The Government will 
also establish and implement, before release of the second tranche of the program loan, a 
mechanism to provide extension support for beneficiaries of social land concessions.  
 
36.  The Government has  given  out  agricultural  concessions  to  private  companies  and 
individuals for commercial farming. The underlying rationale was that large estates, with their 
large-scale investments, would be able to use land more efficiently and productively than 
smallholders. However, most agricultural concession lands remain unused without generating

38.  During the 1990s Cambodia's transition from a centrally planned to a free market 
economy affected the supply of agricultural inputs, including improved seeds (para. 15). The 
Government recognizes that a modern private seed sector needs to be developed to increase 
production and delivery of quality seeds to farmers. The Government will finalize the draft seed 
law through consultations with key stakeholders, and submit it to the National Assembly for 
approval before the release of the second tranche of the program loan. In accordance with the 
envisioned law, public research institutes such as CARDI will focus on basic research, variety 
development, and foundation seed production, with the private sector engaged in multiplication 
and distribution under a new regulatory framework.  
 
39.  The Government introduced a legal framework to ensure the quality and environmental 
standards of agricultural inputs. The Bureau of Agricultural Materials Standards, which was 
established for this purpose, has 7 staff and 47 provincial inspectors, who received training on 
the  inspection  and  management  of  agricultural  inputs.  In  October  2002  the  Government 
approved  the  guidelines  for  local-level  implementation  of  the  subdecree.  Awareness  of 
agrochemical quality and requirements for handling agrochemicals will be widely disseminated 
to farmers through the extension system. During ASDP, the bureau will distribute the guidelines 
in Khmer language and complete training and seminars for provincial staff and private traders, 
and, before release of the second tranche of the loan, establish an appropriate inspection 
system in collaboration with other government agencies.

were in poor condition due to weak management, unskilled tapping, inadequate maintenance, 
old  trees  and  theft.  In  March  1999  these  estates were converted into self-financing public 
enterprises, which are still owned by the Government and being operated under restrictions of 
bureaucratic procedures and weak marketing mechanisms (para. 17). To reverse the current

41.  Over the past 2 years, AIC has been transformed into a state-owned public enterprise 
with its own statute, and registered as a company with Ministry of Commerce. However, AIC 
has been unable to fulfill its mandate as an autonomous enterprise without government support, 
and  still  uses  scarce  fiscal  resources  for  unproductive  purposes.  Under  the  new  market 
environment of increased competition from the private sector, the Government recognizes the 
need to complete divestment of AIC. KAMFIMEX was restructured into an autonomous public 
enterprise in September 2002, and its role in the market greatly reduced. However, state 
ownership of KAMFIMEX still gives a high level of market uncertainty as direct state intervention

acceptable to ADB, to carry out auditing according to internationally accepted standards before

mandates of MAFF's departments during ASP, then rationalize them, and approve a new

D.  The Project Loan 
1.  Objectives 
61.  The project loan will provide farmers with effective agricultural support services, and has 
been  designed  as  a  pilot  project  to  achieve  the  ASDP's  objectives  for  increased 
commercialization of agriculture and reduce rural poverty. The project loan will help establish a 
mechanism  to  increase  participation  of  farming  households  in  the  rural  economy  through 
improved productivity and diversification into more marketable, higher-value commodities (crop, 
livestock, and fishery), and through greater integration of producers into marketing, processing, 
and related service activities. Together with the JFPR project, the project loan will provide a 
framework for future MAFF extension activities in other provinces and linkages to agro-based 
enterprise development. 
 
2.  Components and Outputs 
a.  Extension Support for Farmer Groups 
62.  In Cambodia, the potential for rice production to further enhance farmers’ livelihoods is 
limited. The small size of landholdings (usually less than 2 ha) and low yields, combined with 
demands  of  household  consumption  and  low  unit  value,  limit  the  size  and  value  of  any 
marketable surplus. Although some opportunities remain to increase yield of rice for export, 
improvements in household incomes for rural households must come from diversification into 
alternative  high-value  products  and  from  increased  participation  in  the  marketing  and 
downstream processing of agro-based commodities and related agribusiness services. Most 
farmers, however, have limited access to new and improved technologies (knowledge, skills, or 
inputs), and are poorly organized to take advantage of either production or market opportunities. 
As  shown  in  NGOs'  rural  development  projects  and  donor-supported  activities  through 
provincial departments of agriculture, forestry, and fisheries (PDAFFs), the use of farmer groups 
is not only effective for delivering support services to individual farmers but also enables such 
services to offer an extended outreach to communes and villages.26

to farmer groups. Particular attention will be paid to the needs of women farmers with respect to 
functional literacy programs and to the scheduling, materials and accommodation arrangements

regarding  the  composition  of  farmer  groups  and  contents  of  the  training  programs.  The 
extension support component is expected to benefit about 2,800 farmer groups in the four

b.  Support Services for Agro-Based Enterprises 
66.  Cambodia has a large number of micro agroenterprises, each usually comprising a few 
family members and temporary workers. The enterprises are organized as sole proprietorships, 
rarely registered, and do not rely on formal credit for investment capital. To integrate farmers 
into rapidly growing urban and international markets, it is important, particularly in rural areas, to 
promote market linkages between farmers and these enterprises and traders. However, growth 
of micro- and small-scale agroenterprises is constrained by weak infrastructure, limited access 
to credit, and limited information. No institutional framework provides relevant information on 
their  common  issues  and  business  opportunities.  Even  the  simplest  data  on  how  many 
agroenterprises operate in a certain area and in which field, and their size, are not easily 
available outside Phnom Penh. With the exception of a few NGOs, no institutional mechanism 
provides such business information and services to agroenterprises.

68.  In the agriculture sector, public institutions to promote marketing and export of agro-

increasing range of agricultural exports will become even more important. To address these

AGRICULTURE SECTOR IN CAMBODIA 
A.  Crop Production 
 
1.  Cambodia's agriculture is dominated by rice cultivation, which takes up about 2.3 million 
hectares (ha) or 90% of the total cropped area, mainly in the lowland areas along the Mekong 
River and Tonle Sap Lake. There are two main seasons for rice production. Dry-season rice, 
which accounts for about 0.8 million tons (t) or 20% of total rice production of about 4.0 million t, 
is cultivated from December to March, mainly for sale, and largely consists of high-yielding 
varieties developed under the project supported by the International Rice Research Institute and 
the Government of Australia. The yield of dry-season rice was estimated at about 3.2 t/ha in 
2001. Wet-season rice, which accounts for about 3.2 million t or 80% of total rice production, is 
usually cultivated from May to September, and consists mainly of local varieties for domestic 
consumption. Average yield is about 1.9 t/ha. While the average annual production growth of 
dry-season  rice  from  1996  to  2000  (4.8%)  exceeded  that  of  wet  season  rice  (2.8%), 
Cambodians prefer the taste and quality of local varieties and so continue to grow them. 
Farmers’ access to irrigation water is still significantly limited, with the  irrigated area for rice 
estimated at about 473,000 ha in 1997/98 or about 16% of the total rice area, which is mostly for 
supplementary wet-season irrigation.  During the past decade, the country has become self-
sufficient in rice and is able to export a modest surplus. Even though the exact amount of this 
surplus is not known due to the largely informal nature of the rice trade, it is estimated that 
about 400,000 t of paddy and about 50,000 t of milled rice were exported in 2001. 
 
2.  Other major crops are maize (71,500 ha), vegetables (33,800 ha), soybean (33,300 ha), 
mung  bean  (25,000  ha),  sesame  (19,200  ha),  cassava  (16,300  ha),  peanut  (10,400  ha), 
sugarcane (7,700 ha), and sweet potato (7,400 ha). Maize production grew rapidly at an 
average rate of about 11% per annum from 1991 to 2000, particularly as a result of improved 
yields and increasing demand for animal feed due to the rapid growth of the poultry industry in 
recent years. The increasing demand for animal feed in the country and in neighboring countries 
is highly advantageous for Cambodia. Maize is mainly produced in Kampong Cham Province 
and other areas in the southern region. Farmers sell their products to traders at the farm gate or 
at village markets. Vegetable production is difficult to interpret. Official statistics report an 
average  annual  decline  of  2%  during  1991–2000,  possibly  reflecting  the  impact  of  some 
unofficial  imports  from  Viet  Nam,  which  may  have  destabilized  the  domestic  market  and 
undermined incentives for local growers to produce vegetables. However, actual production, 
including unrecorded home-garden production, is thought to be substantially greater. Over the 
last decade, soybean production declined marginally, but the last 5 years have seen substantial 
growth by over 10% per annum with about 70% of production going to Viet Nam. Yields and 
quality, however, remain low and vary among producing areas. The limited growth in output of 
mung beans at 1.7% over the decade masks a strong decline of 5.0% over the last five years, 
particularly concentrated in the dry season crop. Kampong Cham and Kandal provinces are the 
primary producing areas of mung beans, which are traded in bulk at markets in Phnom Penh 
together with soybeans, sesame, and peanuts. These markets in Phnom Penh function as 
intermediate markets to transport vegetables and other products to other provinces. 
 
3.  Sesame production expanded rapidly at an average annual growth rate of about 20% 
over the last 5 years, with a significant increase in cultivated area. Sesame is mainly produced 
in  the  southern  provinces  along  the  Mekong  River  before  major  flooding  starts.  Cassava 
production also grew rapidly during the 1990s at an average annual growth rate of about 11% 
due largely to increasing demand from the starch industry in the country and abroad. Peanut 
production achieved reasonable growth overall at 7% per annum largely because of yield and

D.  Vision for Agriculture in Cambodia 
 
17.  Cambodia is now self-sufficient in rice and is constantly exporting rice surplus. Increased 
rice  production  has  helped  improve  food  security  and  set  the  basis  for  agricultural 
commercialization  and  diversification,  which  constitute  the  main  strategic  thrust  of  the 
Government's Second Socioeconomic Development Plan. However, the achievements are still 
fragile because agriculture largely depends on rainfall. Weak water control and lack of improved 
technology make smallholders vulnerable to the vagaries of the weather. Yet, the country is at a 
crucial moment, when strategic decisions need to be made in relation to the future vision of 
agriculture in the medium- to long-term. In this vision, rice will continue to be the main crop in 
terms of cultivated areas, but the importance of rice in terms of value added within the sector 
will decline. The share of higher value-added products such as non-rice crops, fisheries, and 
livestock  has  a  potential  to  increase  as  a  result  of  closer  integration  with  domestic  and 
international markets. Agricultural products may become a driving force for sustainable growth 
and allow Cambodia to benefit from its membership in the World Trade Organization. This vision 
will clearly require concerted efforts to facilitate commercialization of agriculture, diversification 
toward higher-value products, and integration of smallholders with agro-based enterprises. 
 
18.  To achieve this vision for the agriculture sector, the Government will continue the policy 
and institutional reforms initiated under the first Agriculture Sector Program (1996–2000) and 
address remaining sector issues to (i) improve ability of smallholders to raise productivity and 
diversify towards higher-value products, (ii) improve market environment for private agro-based 
enterprise  growth,  and  (iii)  strengthen  institutional  capacity  for  competitive  agricultural 
commercialization. The Government will also promote participation of the poor and women in 
agricultural  production,  marketing,  and  post-production  system  to  enhance  the  impact  of 
agricultural growth on sustainability and poverty reduction.

POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
 
A.  Poverty Impact Assessment1 
 
1.  Poverty in Cambodia largely results from high population growth, inadequate income 
opportunities, low literacy, exclusion, and vulnerability. The rural economy has traditionally been 
constrained by cyclic and chronic problems leading to increased poverty. Low agricultural value-
added growth implies low income for farmers, who make up most of rural population. Low 
growth and uncertainty also imply reduced incentives to invest in the sector, thus weakening 
linkages with the rest of the rural economy and compromising the sector's future sustainability. 
In December 2002 the Government formulated the National Poverty Reduction Strategy (NPRS) 
in line with the  Second  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPII),  and  emphasized  the 
importance of the agriculture sector in maximizing food self-sufficiency and increasing income-
generating opportunities. In the agriculture sector, the Government will implement pro-poor 
strategies to target provinces with high incidence of poverty and food insecurity. 
 
2.  The Agriculture Sector Development Program (ASDP)  will facilitate policy reforms in 
three areas: (i) improve farmers ability to raise productivity and diversify toward high-value 
products, (ii) improve the market environment for private agro-based enterprises, and (iii) 
strengthen  institutional  capacity  for  competitive  agricultural  commercialization.  All  these 
measures will have some direct or indirect impact on poverty reduction. The first policy area 
addresses improvement of legal and regulatory aspects of productive resources and input 
supply, access, and use, with emphasis on poor and low-income farmers. By improving access 
to and use of non-rice land, smallholder investment can be encouraged through secure tenure. 
Farm production may be increased through improved access to and use of irrigation water and 
quality seed, fertilizer and chemicals in input markets. The poor are expected to be major 
beneficiaries in the short to medium term particularly of measures related to land tenure and 
linkage opportunities. The poor will also benefit from quality agricultural inputs, provided they 
are affordable. 
 
3.  Second, divestment of public enterprises will remove distortionary effects of agricultural 
input and output markets and enhance more competitive market environment. Rubber is one of 
the largest agricultural exports but state domination of the industry and inefficiencies constrain 
the subsector’s income-earning and growth potential, and discourage estate and smallholder 
expansion. Smallholders, including the poor, will benefit from an improved market environment 
that will facilitate private agroenterprise growth.  However, this policy area may result in a 
possible short-run reduction in public sector employment during divestment and have possible 
adverse impact on low-income estate workers. Any negative impact needs to be mitigated 
through support for redeployment and provision of opportunities for smallholder plantation 
ownership and operation.2 The divestment of other enterprises, the Agricultural Inputs Company 
(AIC) and the Kampuchea Fish Import and Export Company (KAMFIMEX) will have no adverse 
impact on the poor, but needs to include appropriate social safeguards satisfactory to the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). 
 
4.  The  third  policy  area  of  ASDP  will  require  shifting  of  public  sector  roles  and 
responsibilities to encourage commercial agriculture at the national and local levels. The policy

B.  Gender 
 
5.  Women are generally disadvantaged in accessing essential services and resources to 
overcome poverty, particularly in education (women's literacy rate is 61%, considerably lower 
than men's 83%). Rural women have a higher risk of ill health and bear a substantial burden in 
agricultural production in addition to household duties. Women constitute more than half the 
farming population and carry out most of the rice transplanting and harvesting. They are also 
responsible for seed selection, and milling and pounding for household consumption. Women 
work an average of 25- 45% longer than men each day. Women often tend vegetable gardens 
for home consumption and for sale. Men are normally responsible for the care of large livestock, 
and women for small livestock. The gender division of labor is not entirely rigid but men expect 
to be paid more for remunerative activities than women because of claimed physical strength. 
 
6.  Women carry out well over 90% of reproductive and household duties, including the 
caring for not only the very young and the aged but also, in some cases, adults who are ill or 
disabled. Social obligations are important and time consuming. Women do not get public 
recognition for their supportive role, especially in preparing food for the numerous cultural and 
religious rituals. Women also provide much of the community work, such as ensuring the daily 
feeding of monks or the logistics to organize a major temple festival. Women and men have 
equal rights to legally own land. However, distress sales of land (due to loan default and other 
hardships) among poor female-headed households have been over double that of male-headed 
households. Access to affordable credit and other income-generating opportunities, including 
wage labor, is limited. Participation of women in the political and public sectors remains low 
from the commune to national level. Female extension workers are less than one third of total 
staff complement. The situation is even worse at the MAFF central office, while slightly better in 
provincial  departments  of  agriculture,  forestry,  and  fisheries.  Female  students  are  under- 
represented in all institutions that offer tertiary education in agriculture.  
 
C.  Socioeconomic Profile of the Project Area 
 
7.  Based on a socioeconomic assessment, 4 provinces in the southern region have been 
identified as the project area for ASDP's project component in view of their production and 
marketing potential of high-value products, and synergy with other projects in the agriculture 
sector. The project provinces are Kampong Cham, Kampong Speu, Kampot, and Takeo, with a 
population of about 3.5 million or 31% of the country's population. Land area ranges from 9,420 
square kilometers (km2) in Kampong Cham to 3,490 km2 in Takeo. On average, more than 89% 
of labor force in these provinces is engaged in agriculture. Life expectancy at birth varies but is 
mostly in the late 50s. Kampong Speu has the highest total fertility rate of 6, and highest infant 
and child mortality rates of 80 and 53, respectively. 
 
8.  There are pockets of serious poverty, especially in Kampong Cham. These poor areas 
are particularly vulnerable to floods and other natural disasters. In the project provinces, the

D.  Possible Social Risks and Mitigation Measures 
 
13.  Under ASDP, the Government will facilitate implementation of the 2001 Land Law by 
putting  in  place  the  subdecrees  on  social  land  concessions  and  on  reduction  of  unused 
economic land concessions. Selected landless people will be settled in areas to be made 
available under the social land concession programs. ADB discussed possible social risks with 
the Government and agreed to include in the subdecree requirements for detailed social and 
environmental impact assessments for all social land concession programs. These measures 
will identify possible social and environmental risks  involved in each concession program. A 
detailed field survey will be first carried out by the World Bank for a pilot social concession 
program under its Land Management and Administration Project. ADB will closely monitor the 
progress and continue its dialogue during ASDP. 
 
14.  Liquidation of unsustainable public enterprises may lead to short-term redundancies. 
The Government has established a committee to manage divestment of the rubber estates, AIC, 
and KAMFIMEX, and address labor issues. There are about 15,500 employees in seven state-
owned rubber estates. About 12,000 casual workers are engaged in rubber planting, production 
and  transport  activities  on  a  contract  basis.  Other  employees  include  managerial  and 
administrative staff, teachers, health workers, security guards, and drivers. Most employees 
likely to be affected will be among the less poor, including administrative and managerial staff 
(about  700).  Teachers  and  health  workers  are  expected  to  be  absorbed  in  the  relevant 
ministries or provincial authorities. The Government formulated a plan for the divestment of the 
seven rubber estates in 1998. This plan needs to be updated and revised based on the external 
audit of the estates to be carried out by the national divestment committee. A resettlement 
policy framework has also been prepared to address the inadequacy of the existing legal 
provisions in Cambodia. This policy is based on the idea that ASDP must serve the needs of 
society and ensure that the program affected people are at least as well-off due to divestment of 
public enterprises. 
 
15.  Divestment of AIC (55 staff) and KAMFIMEX (about 300 staff) will increase efficiency in 
the use of scarce public resources, remove market uncertainties, and contribute to the growth of 
private agro-based enterprises, thereby creating more employment opportunities in the medium 
term. During dialogue with ADB, the Government indicated its policy to absorb as many staff as 
possible  through  redeployment  within  MAFF.  However,  some  staff  members  need  to  be 
separated if the enterprises are to be liquidated.  The Labor Law requires the employer to 
provide the employee with a specified minimum notice period before separation and a minimum 
severance benefit. According to other instances of divestment in Cambodia, actual terms and 
conditions are usually determined during direct negotiations between the investor, who is 
interested in purchasing the assets of the concerned public enterprise, and the Government, 
which is usually represented by Ministry of Economy and Finance and the concerned line

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Agriculture Sector Development Program (ASDP) consists of policy-based program 
and investment project components. This section discusses the financial and economic benefits of 
ASDP expected under these two components. A narrative assessment has been done for the 
program component although preliminary estimates are also indicated for the adjustment costs 
required for major policy and institutional reforms. With regard to the project component, financial 
and economic analyses have been carried out quantitatively on the incremental cost and benefit 
streams of the extension support for farmer groups. 
 
B.  Program Component 
 
2.  The program component combines efforts to liberalize key agricultural markets, and 
focuses on institutional reform and strengthening. Institutional reforms are a medium-term 
process given the time required to establish institutional systems, build staff capacity, monitor 
agricultural trades, and implement regulations nationwide, and to realign budgets to deliver 
decentralized support services. 
 
3.  The benefits associated with improved access to land will be generated from increased 
security of land property rights, which will provide incentives to poor and landless farmers to make 
unused land productive. Several farmers are already living on the land envisaged in social land 
concession programs or borders of economic concession lands. This is in fact, one of the main 
reasons for the failure of economic concessions that were given without considering the needs of 
local communities or landless people. The costs required for the reforms on land concessions will 
include those for rural development support for the beneficiaries of social land concessions to 
sustain  their  livelihoods.  The  Government's  social  land  concession  programs  will  not  be 
effective unless accompanied by land titling and agricultural support services to newly titled 
smallholders. The rural development support costs for the program will include those for land-
use surveys, titling, agricultural extension support and infrastructure. There will also be costs for 
increased public awareness campaigns on the subdecree for social land concessions and the 
2001 Land Law. Compensation payments may be also required to defray investment costs of 
the developers of unused and subsequently revoked economic concessions. 
 
4.  The expected benefits generated from divestment of state-owned rubber estates are of 
two  types.  The  first  relates  to  the  lower  cost  of  production  resulting  from  more  efficient 
enterprises and work force. The second type relates to additional investment in new assets and 
the consequent increase in future revenues generated from higher profits from rubber or other 
products. Cost efficiency will be realized gradually one over the medium term. In the short run, 
there may be costs required to provide compensation packages for some redundant staff. To 
effect divestment of rubber estates, redundancy packages and provision of support services for 
displaced workers may be required, for which the program loan will generate counterpart funds. 
 
5.  Benefits expected from strengthening of agricultural institutions are mostly indirect and 
to be generated from a more effective role of the public sector to facilitate the market-oriented 
agricultural growth. Rationalization of the institutional functions of the Ministry of Agriculture, 
Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF) will require staff training to be provided under the project loan. In 
addition, the program loan will support the expanded role and geographic coverage of MAFF in 
regulating  quality  of  seeds,  fertilizers,  and  agrochemicals,  as  well  as  in  providing  market 
information services.

6.  The Government decided to introduce a medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF) 
for budget planning in priority sectors, including the agriculture sector.1 This will strengthen the 
linkage between annual expenditures for the sector and overall development plans such as the 
Second  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPII)  and  the  National  Poverty  Reduction 
Strategy.  In  view  of  the  importance  of  the  agriculture  sector,  the  allocation  of  public 
expenditures for the sector needs to increase rapidly in line with SEDPII.2 The overall budget 
ceiling for the agriculture sector needs to increase from about 2% to the range of 5–10%, which 
is the level adopted for other priority sectors. It is estimated that an incremental budget of about 
$20  million  will  be  required  for  the  agriculture  sector  in  the  medium  term.  During  ASDP 
implementation, ADB will continue its dialogue with the Government for strengthening the MTEF 
for  the  agriculture  sector,  and  promote  adequate  fiscal  allocations  to  facilitate  agricultural 
growth.  ASDP  will  also  improve  the  country's  fiscal  situation  through  potential  revenue 
collections and increased efficiency in the agriculture sector. 
 
7.  Under the program component, ASDP will also contribute to benefit distribution in favor 
of the poor through (i) increased public awareness of the legal framework related to the 2001 
Land  Law  and  related  subdecrees,  (ii)  progress  in  implementing  social  land  concession 
programs  for  the  poor,  (iii)  divestment  of  state-owned  rubber  estates  and  other  public 
enterprises that will benefit rubber smallholders and small-scale enterprises in the private 
sector, and (iv) increased fiscal resources to local administrations to deliver public agricultural 
extension services. 
 
C.  Project Component 
 
  1.  Approach and Assumptions 
 
8.  Financial and economic analyses were carried out for the project component of ASDP 
based on typical cropping patterns in the project area, and expected aggregate costs and 
benefits. It is assumed that the project benefits are expected from farmers' adoption of new 
technology through extension support for farmer groups. Other benefits indirectly generated 
from ASDP's program component and other project activities relating to support services for 
agro-based  enterprises  and  institutional  capacity  building  will  significantly  enhance  project 
benefits but have not been quantified in the analyses. The economic life of the project is 
assumed to be 20 years. The prices of project inputs and outputs are those prevailing during the 
surveys conducted in June 2002 in the project area.3 
 
9.  The present Government policies in line with SEDPII are assumed to remain during the 
project period, and general inflation relating to project inputs and outputs will not have a 
substantial impact on relative prices. The analysis also assumes that the Government will 
effectively implement the policy and institutional reforms under ASDP to ensure adequate 
budgetary allocations for public extension agents to achieve project objectives. The primary 
data and information for the analysis were collected in the project provinces during the field 
surveys, and recent data on farm-household production were available from various secondary 
sources related to the ongoing agriculture projects. These data have been used to construct

10.  Project activities will be implemented in the southern region of Cambodia where there

directly benefit under the project. The cumulative number of participating farmer groups will 
reach 2,800 by project completion and about 56,000 farm households (20 farmers in a group) 
will receive direct benefits under the project. 
 
2.  Cropping Patterns 
 
11.  Gradual changes in cropping patterns are expected under the project through farmers' 
increased adoption of new agricultural technology and commercial crops. In a few villages in the 
project provinces, rapid changes have been achieved by nongovernment organizations and 
under the Special Programme for Food Security initiated by the Government with assistance 
from the Food and Agriculture Organization. The project area is mostly in the rain-fed lowland 
region where most farmers cultivate rain-fed paddy during May–September.5 According to the 
field survey conducted in the project provinces during preparation of ASDP, at least about 70% 
of cropped area is devoted to rice. Non-rice crops include corn and other cereals, various 
vegetables, beans, pulses, and fruits. 
 
12.  The project will promote more efficient and commercially viable cropping patterns by 
increasing access to improved inputs, and information on technology and marketing. Both non-
poor and poor farmers are expected to gradually change their cropping patterns and introduce 
commercial production. Farmers will modify commercial cropping patterns more frequently in 
response to changes in local market conditions. With improved access to extension services 
and market information, farmers and their groups will be able to make more informed decisions 
and adopt more efficient farming practices. Cropping intensity is expected to increase slightly 
but remain almost stable in the medium term. 
 
3.  Crop and Farm Budgets 
 
13.  Indicative crop budgets have been established for main crops cultivated in the project 
area and based on farm-gate prices. Rice planting is mainly done through broadcasting in the 
project  area.  Unpaid  family  labor  is  the  primary  source  of  unskilled  labor.  Hired  labor  is 
estimated to cost about KR3,900 ($1) per day. In some areas where transplanting is practiced,

14.  Cambodian farmers consider rice a highly important staple food and strongly emphasize 
secure rice production. Farmers, particularly poor farmers with small landholdings, are thus not 
expected to reduce their cropped area for wet-season rice. Under the project, incremental 
financial benefits for farmers will mainly come from higher margins gained from improved 
productivity and increased production of high-value crops. 
 
4.  Project Economic Costs and Benefits 
 
15.  The indicative economic viability of the project has been assessed in aggregate based 
on the economic prices of farm inputs and outputs. Border prices have been taken from the 
World Bank's global market prices (constant 2002 prices), and a world price numeraire is used 
for the analysis. The economic prices of local and high-yielding rice varieties have been 
estimated at the border on an import- and export-parity bases as appropriate, and adjusted for 
non-tradable costs, including handling and transportation, with a standard conversion factor of 
0.9, and labor contents with a shadow wage rate of 0.9.6 Project cost items for extension 
support for farmer groups, which are mostly non-tradable items, have also been adjusted with 
the standard conversion factor. The economic internal rate of return for the project is 39% and 
economic net present value at a 12% discount rate is KR40,234 million ($10.3 million).

project to be viable for these different scenarios (Table A12).
